{{Infobox NFL season | team = Kansas City Chiefs | year = 2009 | record = 4â12 | division_place = 4th [[AFC West]] | coach = [[Todd Haley]] | stadium = [[Arrowhead Stadium]] | playoffs = ''did not qualify'' | pro bowlers = | uniform = | next = [[2010 Kansas City Chiefs season|2010]] }} The '''[[2009 NFL season|2009]] [[Kansas City Chiefs]] season''' was the franchise's 50th season, and first with head coach [[Todd Haley]] at the helm. It was also the first season with [[Scott Pioli]] as the team's general manager. The Chiefs attempted to improve on their 2â14 record from [[2008 Kansas City Chiefs season|2008]] with the third overall selection in the [[2009 NFL Draft]].{{cite web | title=Lions to pick first, 20th in first round | url=http://myespn.go.com/blogs/nflnation/0-4-620/Lions-to-pick-first--20th-in-first-round.html | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2008-12-29 | accessdate=2009-01-09}} In 2009, the Chiefs also honored the induction of [[Derrick Thomas]], the team's former linebacker from 1989 to 1999, into the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]].{{cite web | title=Derrick Thomas elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame's Class of 2009 | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/01/31/derrick_thomas_elected_to_the_pro_football_hall_of_fames_class_of_2009/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-01-31 | accessdate=2009-02-06}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Thomas' jersey number 58 was officially retired by the franchise after having been unissued since Thomas' death in 2000.{{cite web | title=LB Derrick Thomas had his #58 retired, family received HOF ring at Arrowhead vs. Denver on December 8th | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/06/23/lb_derrick_thomas_will_have_his_58_retired_family_to_receive_hof_ring_at_arrowhead_vs_denver_on_december_6th/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-06-23 | accessdate=2009-06-23}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The fate of head coach Herman Edwards and his staff remained uncertain after the end of the 2008 season in which the Chiefs finished with a franchise-worst 2â14 record. The team was 6â26 in the past two years under Edwards, who had one year left on a four-year, $12 million contract and was lobbying to be allowed another year to get his rebuilding movement off the ground. Team owner [[Clark Hunt]] voiced his support of Edwards, but he had also said the new general manager [[Scott Pioli]] would have "significant input" into the decision on whether to retain him. On January 23, the Chiefs fired Edwards, and on February 5, [[Todd Haley]] was hired as the 11th head coach in Chiefs franchise history and signed a four-year contract.{{cite web | title=Source: Cards assistant tabbed to coach Chiefs | url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/9187366/Sources:-Cards-assistant-tabbed-to-coach-Chiefs | last=Glazer | first=Jay | publisher=Fox Sports | date=2009-02-05 | accessdate=2009-02-06}}{{cite web | title=Todd Haley named Kansas City Chiefs head coach | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/02/06/todd_haley_named_kansas_city_chiefs_head_coach/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-02-06 | accessdate=2009-02-06}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web | title=Chiefs hire Cardinals offensive coordinator Haley as coach | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80e9b58a&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true | author=Associated Press | date=2009-02-06 | accessdate=2009-02-06}} For the 2009 season under the Pioli/Haley regime, the Chiefs switched from a [[4â3 defense]] to a [[3â4 defense|3â4 defensive strategy]]. Although finishing the regular season last in the [[AFC West]] with a record of 4â12, the Chiefs doubled their win record from the previous season. ==Schedule== ===Preseason=== {| class="wikitable" align="center" style="font-size: 92%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week ! rowspan="2" | Date ! rowspan="2" | Kickoff ([[Central Time Zone|CDT]]) ! rowspan="2" | Opponent ! colspan="2" | Results ! rowspan="2" | Game Site ! rowspan="2" | TV

â  These three games were among the 16 that the NFL designated as "AFL Legacy Games", in honor of the 50th anniversary of the [[American Football League|AFL]]. The Chiefs (formerly the Dallas Texans) wore their throwback uniforms during those three games, as did the Cowboys, Chargers and Raiders.http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d81029dc6&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true |} ==Standings== {{2009 AFC West standings}} ==Offseason== ===AFL anniversary season=== In select games, the Chiefs, as well as the other founding teams of the [[American Football League]], will wear "throwback" uniforms to celebrate the AFL's 50th anniversary and the [[1962 Dallas Texans season|1962 Dallas Texans]] team that won the AFL Championship.{{cite web | title=Chiefs to unveil "throwback" AFL uniforms in 2009 | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/24/chiefs_to_unveil_throwback_afl_uniforms_in_2009/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-24 | accessdate=2009-03-24}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The Chiefs "throwback" look will feature helmets with gray facemasks and a [[Texas]]-shaped decal with a gold star showing the location of the city of [[Dallas, Texas]]. From 1960 to 1962, the team was known as the Dallas Texans and played at the [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]] alongside the NFL's [[Dallas Cowboys]]. Jerseys for the clubâs "throwback" games will include a patch that honors the AFLâs 50th anniversary. Kansas City will wear these replica uniforms when they host the Dallas Cowboys at Arrowhead Stadium and against two AFC West opponents yet to be determined (one home date and one away date). The team's decision to wear the Texans' helmets started a controversy with some Chiefs fans who believed the team needed to honor the franchise's years in Kansas City, not Dallas.{{cite web | title=Honoring history crosses all borders | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/27/honoring_history_crosses_all_borders/ | last=Gretz | first=Bob | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-27 | accessdate=2009-03-27}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} A petition by [[WHB|Sports Radio 810 WHB]] in Kansas City states that "the Chiefs have a responsibility to help promote the state and region that have supported them financially through stadium taxes, ticket sales, parking fees, concessions and merchandise sales for 47 years."{{Cite web |url=http://www.jotform.com/form/90822940333 |title=Kansas City Chiefs Uniform Petition |author=Sports Radio 810 WHB |accessdate=2009-03-27}} ===General manager search=== [[Image:Pioli.png|left|thumb|Scott Pioli was hired on January 13.]] {{Quote box | quote =With his proven track record of success, Scott is the finest player personnel executive in the NFL, and we look forward to his leadership in building a championship organization. | source = â Clark Hunt on hiring Scott Pioli as general manager. | width =33% | align =right }} Following the resignation of [[Carl Peterson]], the Chiefs' general manager, chief executive officer, and team president, a search for the team's new general manager began.{{cite web | title=Chairman of the Board Clark Hunt Press Conference on the resignation of Carl Peterson | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2008/12/15/chairman_of_the_board_clark_hunt_pc/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2008-12-15 | accessdate=2008-12-15}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web | title=Chiefs' Carl Peterson resigns; Edwards' future uncertain | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/chiefs/2008-12-15-peterson-out_N.htm?csp=34 | work=USA Today | author=Associated Press | date=2008-12-15 | accessdate=2008-12-15}} Chiefs owner [[Clark Hunt]] said he intended to split the three jobs that Peterson held for nearly 20 years, looking for "a shrewd evaluator of football talent" at the general manager's position. Possible candidates included former Chiefs head coach [[Marty Schottenheimer]],{{cite web | title=Few leaks in Chiefs' GM search| url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2008/12/28/three-strong-candidates-for-chiefs-gm-job/ | last=Schefter | first=Adam | publisher=NFL.com | accessdate=2009-01-11}}{{cite web | title=Sunday Scoops: Glazer's latest coaching update | url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/8996898/Sunday-Scoops:-Glazer's-latest-coaching-update | last=Glazer | first=Jay | publisher=Fox Sports | date=2008-12-28 | accessdate=2009-01-25}} [[Indianapolis Colts]] vice president of football operations [[Chris Polian]],{{cite web | title=Next Chiefs' GM expected to bring in his own coach | url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2009/01/04/chiefs-next-gm-expected-to-bring-in-his-own-coach/ | last=Schefter | first=Adam | publisher=NFL.com | accessdate=2009-01-05}}{{cite web | title=Three strong candidates for Chiefs' GM job | url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2008/12/28/three-strong-candidates-for-chiefs-gm-job/ | last=Schefter | first=Adam | publisher=NFL.com | accessdate=2009-01-05}} [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] director of pro personnel [[Mark Dominik]], former [[Denver Broncos]] general manager [[Ted Sundquist]], former [[Tennessee Titans]] general manager [[Floyd Reese]], [[San Diego Chargers]] director of player personnel [[Jimmy Raye III]], [[Baltimore Ravens]] director of college scouting [[Eric DeCosta]],{{cite web | title=A dozen Super Bowl matchups to root for | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/don_banks/01/02/playoffs/1.html | publisher=SI.com | date=2009-01-02 | accessdate=2009-01-02}} and [[New England Patriots]] vice president of football operations [[Scott Pioli]].{{cite web | title=Report: Browns want Pioli decision soon | url= http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3803935 | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-01-01 | accessdate=2009-01-01}} Hunt said he would hire a new person to overlook football operations and a second person to be in charge of the team's business operations.{{cite web | title=Chiefs talking with Pioli about GM vacancy | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/nfl/01/05/chiefs.ap/index.html | author=Associated Press | date=2009-01-05 | accessdate=2009-01-05 | publisher=SI.com}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} That job, team president, was given to longtime team executive vice president [[Denny Thum]].{{cite web | title=Denny Thum named Kansas City Chiefs president | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/05/08/denny_thum_named_kansas_city_chiefs_president/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-05-08 | accessdate=2009-05-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Pioli reportedly sought "total control" of an organization and was also pursued by the [[Cleveland Browns]] to be their new general manager. Pioli's supposed intentions of "total control" could have possibly eliminated him from the Chiefs' job. Hunt had kept his search almost entirely leak-proof, instructing subordinates that only he is to speak to the situation. Hunt also intended to be thorough and patient in his search for the Chiefs' new general manager. Pioli was reportedly the Chiefs' number one candidate and on January 13 the Chiefs hired Pioli as general manager.{{cite web | title=Scott Pioli to join Kansas City Chiefs | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3830515 | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-01-13 | accessdate=2009-01-13}}{{cite web | title=Scott Pioli named Kansas City Chiefs general manager | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/01/13/scott_pioli_named_kansas_city_chiefs_general_manager/ | date=2009-01-13 | accessdate=2009-01-14 | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The official statement from the Chiefs said that Pioli would "have final say over all football operations and report directly to (Clark) Hunt." The Chiefs introduced Pioli the following day at team headquarters in Kansas City. ===Coaching changes=== ====Hiring Todd Haley==== The decision to hire Scott Pioli as general manager likely meant that head coach [[Herman Edwards]] would not return for a fourth season as Chiefs head coach. The ''[[Kansas City Star]]'' reported that according to two coaches, Edwards and his staff could have been dismissed as soon as Wednesday, January 14, the day when Pioli was introduced in Kansas City.{{cite web | title=Clark Hunt introduces General Manager Scott Pioli | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/01/14/clark_hunt_introduces_general_manager_scott_pioli/ | date=2009-01-14 | accessdate=2009-01-15}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} At his press conference, Pioli did not rule out Edwards being retained as the team's head coach. Hunt said publicly that he wanted Edwards to return in 2009, but Pioli would have "significant input" in the final decision. Several candidates were mentioned as possible replacements for Edwards even before he had been fired. The most notable names mentioned were [[Todd Haley]], the offensive coordinator of the 2008 NFC Champion [[Arizona Cardinals]], [[New York Giants]] defensive coordinator [[Steve Spagnuolo]], and [[Mike Shanahan]], the former head coach of the Chiefs' rival Raiders and Broncos franchises.{{cite web | title=Mike Shanahan could be next Chiefs head coach | url=http://www.nbcactionnews.com/sports/story/Mike-Shanahan-Could-be-Next-Chiefs-Head-Coach/EjWyJUYPT0q-lAAApuqgXw.cspx | last=Harry | first=Jack | publisher=NBC Action News, Kansas City | date=2009-01-21 | accessdate=2009-01-22}}{{cite web | title=Herm out, Shanahan In? | url=http://www.profootballtalk.com/2009/01/22/herm-out-shanahan-in/ | last=Florio | first=Mike | publisher=Pro Football Talk | date=2009-01-21 | accessdate=2009-01-22}} Other possible candidates included [[Jon Gruden]], [[Leslie Frazier]], [[Winston Moss]], [[Kirk Ferentz]], [[Jason Garrett]], and even Scott Pioli's father-in-law, [[Bill Parcells]].{{cite web | title=Kansas city Chiefs Inside Slant | url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/4809758/Kansas-City-Chiefs-Inside-Slant | author=Sports Xchange | publisher=Fox Sports | date=2009-01-24 | accessdate=2009-01-25}} Edwards was fired on January 23, and [[ESPN]]'s [[Chris Mortensen]] reported later that evening that the Chiefs were targeting Mike Shanahan to become the next head coach. Mortensen initially reported that the Chiefs were negotiating on a contract with Shanahan.{{cite web | title=Chiefs fire Edwards; Shanahan next? | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3855917 | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-01-23 | accessdate=2009-01-23}}{{cite web | title=Herm Edwards relieved of duties as Chiefs head coach | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/01/23/herm_edwards_relieved_of_duties_as_chiefs_head_coach/ | date=2009-01-23 | accessdate=2009-01-23 | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The report was later denied by Shanahan himself.{{cite web | title=Shanahan will 'definitely' not coach Chiefs, or anyone else in 2009 | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/nfl/01/24/shanahan.chiefs/index.html | last=King | publisher=Sports Illustrated | first=Peter | date=2009-01-24 | accessdate=2009-01-24}} After a long period in which Haley was considered the front-runner for the head coaching position, there was concern as to whether the Chiefs would violate the [[Rooney Rule]] by immediately hiring Haley. The Rooney Rule, named after Pittsburgh Steelers owner [[Dan Rooney]], specifies that NFL teams must give fair interviews to minority candidates whenever a head coaching position comes open.{{cite web | title=Wooten says KC has interviewed minority candidates | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2009-02-05-4055823280_x.htm | last=Tucker | first=Doug | work=USA Today | date=2009-02-05 | accessdate=2009-02-06}} Some minority coaches were reportedly turning down offers from the Chiefs since Haley was the presumed target for the coaching vacancy. The Chiefs negotiated with Haley following the Cardinals' loss in [[Super Bowl XLIII]], and Haley accepted the coaching position on February 5. Haley was introduced as head coach the following day. Defensive coordinator [[Gunther Cunningham]] was hired by the [[Detroit Lions]] for the same position.{{cite web | title=Lions name Gunther Cunningham as assistant head coach/defensive coordinator | url=http://www.detroitlions.com/document_display.cfm?document_id=480841 | publisher=Detroit Lions | date=2009-01-21 | accessdate=2009-02-19}} Cunningham had been the defensive coordinator for the Chiefs from 1995 to 1998 and 2004 to 2008. He also served as the team's head coach from 1999 to 2000.{{cite web | title=Cunningham to run Lions' defense | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3848485 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-01-21 | accessdate=2009-01-21}} The Chiefs also lost secondary coach [[David Gibbs (football coach)|David Gibbs]] to the [[Houston Texans]] and [[Mike Priefer]] to the [[Denver Broncos]]. Once Todd Haley was hired, the Chiefs fired tight ends coach [[Jon Embree]], defensive assistant/assistant linebacker coach [[Michael Ketchum]], running backs coach [[Curtis Modkins]], offensive assistant/quality control coach [[Kevin Patullo]], and wide receivers coach [[Eric Price]].{{cite web | title=Chiefs announce changes on coaching staff | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/02/13/chiefs_announce_changes_on_coaching_staff/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-02-13 | accessdate=2009-02-14}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ====Assistant coaches and administration==== For Haley's new coaching staff, the Chiefs hired [[Joel Collier]],{{cite web | title=Kansas City Chiefs announce coaching staff moves | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/02/17/kansas_city_chiefs_announce_coaching_staff_moves/ | date=2009-02-17 | accessdate=2009-02-17 | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} [[Gary Gibbs]] (linebackers),{{cite web | title=Ex-Cards coordinator gets Chiefs' job | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3978236 | last=Pasquarelli | first=Len | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-03-13 | accessdate=2009-03-13}} Steve Hoffman (special teams), [[Bill Muir]] (offensive line), [[Clancy Pendergast]] (defensive coordinator), [[Pat Perles]], [[Dedric Ward]] (wide receivers), [[Ronnie Bradford]] (defensive assistant),{{cite web | title=Kansas City Chiefs add Ronnie Bradford, Nick Sirianni to staff | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/03/kansas_city_chiefs_add_ronnie_bradford_nick_sirianni_to_coaching_staff/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-03 | accessdate=2009-03-03}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} [[Nick Sirianni]] (offensive quality control coach), and [[Maurice Carthon]] (assistant head coach).{{cite web | title=Kansas City Chiefs add Maurice Carthon to coaching staff | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/02/19/kansas_city_chiefs_add_maurice_carthon_to_coaching_staff/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-02-19 | accessdate=2009-02-19}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} From Herman Edwards' staff, [[Chan Gailey]] was retained as offensive coordinator, and [[Bob Bicknell]] switched from offensive line to tight ends coach, and [[Joe D'Alessandris]] was retained as assistant offensive line coach. The Chiefs also relieved duties of several scouts and player personnel assistants once the [[2009 NFL Draft]] concluded.{{cite web | title=Chiefs announce changes and retentions in player personnel department | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/05/01/chiefs_announce_changes_and_retentions_in_player_personnel_department/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-05-01 | accessdate=2009-05-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Initially there were doubts as to whether Chan Gailey would retained under Todd Haley's coaching staff, being that Haley had just concluded a successful stint as offensive coordinator at Arizona. After the Chiefs lost their first three pre-season games, Gailey was relieved of duties and Haley is expected to assume offensive playcalling duties.{{cite web | title=Gailey no longer running Chiefs offense | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4434133 | publisher=ESPN.com | last=Clayton | first=John | date=2009-08-31 | accessdate=2009-08-31}} ===Roster changes and trade demands=== Immediately following the Chiefs' 2008 season finale loss to the [[Cincinnati Bengals]], RB [[Larry Johnson (American football)|Larry Johnson]] voiced his intention to seek a trade in the offseason.{{cite web | title=Chiefs' Johnson wants out after season-ending loss to Bengals | url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/recap?game_id=29771&displayPage=tab_recap&season=2008&week=REG17&override=true | author=Associated Press | publisher=NFL.com | date=2008-12-28 | accessdate=2008-12-28}} Johnson was involved in legal troubles in 2008 and his production on the field declined. As a result of his legal troubles, in March 2009 Johnson pleaded guilty to the two incidents that occurred in 2008 and was sentenced to two years [[probation]].{{cite web | title=RB Johnson gets probation for assaults | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4021992 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-03-27 | accessdate=2009-03-27}} Johnson served suspensions from the NFL in 2008 and is not expected to receive further punishment from the charges. OL [[Brian Waters]] had issues with Todd Haley shortly after Haley's hiring, saying the coach had been disrespectful of him during a meeting, then that new general manager Scott Pioli refused to meet with him privately.{{cite web | title=Players still getting used to Haley's fiery style of coaching | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d810eb4b0&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true | publisher=NFL.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-06-21 | accessdate=2009-06-21}} Waters later told the ''[[Kansas City Star]]'' that he wanted to be traded and did not attend any of the team's voluntary offseason workouts. Newly acquired LB [[Mike Vrabel]] also did not attend offseason workouts citing his rights with the league's [[collective bargaining]] agreement. TE [[Tony Gonzalez (tight end)|Tony Gonzalez]] reiterated his intentions for a trade in March 2009 after a failed attempt in October 2008.{{cite web | title=Chiefs TE Gonzalez still interested in being traded, source says | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80f6f179&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true | publisher=NFL.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-03-25 | accessdate=2009-03-25}} He was eventually traded in April to the [[Atlanta Falcons]]. Gonzalez lobbied for the Chiefs to keep [[Tyler Thigpen]] as the team's starting quarterback when Gonzalez was still with the team and when Matt Cassel was not yet on the Chiefs roster.{{cite web | title=Gonzalez: It's a 'disgrace' if Chiefs don't stick with Thigpen in '09 | url=http://content.usatoday.com/topics/post/People/Athletes/NFL/Tyler+Thigpen/59802778.blog/1 | work=USA Today | last=Leahy | first=Sean | date=2008-12-10 | accessdate=2009-01-10}} Though he appeared to be the Chiefs' lone quarterback who would remain in their plans for 2009,{{cite web | title=Worth a look | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2008/11/20/worth_a_look/ | date=2008-11-20 | accessdate=2008-12-24 | last=Rand | first=Jonathan | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} especially after [[Damon Huard]] was released Thigpen was not considered a lock for the starting job.{{cite web | title=Questions abound as Chiefs fall to Bengals | url=http://kan.scout.com/2/825139.html | last=Athan | first=Nick | publisher=Warpaint Illustrated (Scout.com) | date=2008-12-28 | accessdate=2008-12-28}} Thigpen competed with Matt Cassel for the starting quarterback position.{{cite web | title=Q&A with head coach Todd Haley | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/02/qa_with_todd_haley_3_2_09/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-02 | accessdate=2009-03-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ====Departures==== [[File:Tony Gonzalez at 2005 Pro Bowl 050213-N-3019M-002.jpg|left|thumb|After several trade attempts in the previous year, Tony Gonzalez was traded to Atlanta in April.]] In February, the Chiefs released LB [[Donnie Edwards]], QB [[Damon Huard]], TE [[Michael Merritt (American football)|Michael Merritt]], and CB [[Patrick Surtain]].{{cite web | title=Chiefs announce four transactions | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/02/24/chiefs_announce_four_transactions/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-02-24 | accessdate=2009-02-24}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In March, QB [[Quinn Gray]] was released.{{cite web | title=Chiefs terminate QB Quinn Gray | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/11/chiefs_terminate_qb_quinn_gray/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-11 | accessdate=2009-03-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and in April WR [[Will Franklin (American football)|Will Franklin]], OT [[Andrew Carnahan]], LB [[Curtis Gatewood]], and WR [[Kevin Robinson]] were released. On April 23 the Chiefs traded TE [[Tony Gonzalez (American football)|Tony Gonzalez]] to the Atlanta Falcons in exchange for a second round draft pick in the 2010 NFL Draft.{{cite web | title=Chiefs trade Gonzalez for 2010 draft pick | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4092471 | author=Associated Press | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-04-23 | accessdate=2009-04-23}} In 2008 Gonzalez asked Chiefs management for a trade but negotiations failed and new general manager [[Scott Pioli]] reitereated that Gonzalez was initially not offered in trades for the 2009 season but agreed when the Falcons offered a second-round pick. Gonzalez had sought a trade in the 2008 season but several attempts failed.{{cite web | title=Source: Chiefs willing to listen to offers for record-setting TE Gonzalez | last=Smith | first=Michael | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3638551 | work=ESPN | date=2008=2008-10-12 | accessdate=2008-10-21}}{{cite web | title=Gonzalez tells teammates he's not bitter about failed trade request | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3645516 | work=ESPN | date=2008-10-16 | accessdate=2008-10-21}} At the conclusion of the preseason, the Chiefs released 13 players to reach the 53-player limit. Permanently released were S [[Bernard Pollard]], WR [[Ashley Lelie]], WR [[Taurus Johnson]], DT [[Derek Lokey]], S [[Ricky Price]], and LB [[Zach Thomas]].{{cite web | title=Chiefs announce roster moves | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/09/05/chiefs_announce_roster_moves/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-09-05 | accessdate=2009-09-05}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} CB [[Jackie Bates]], TE [[Tom Crabtree (American football)|Tom Crabtree]], DE [[Dion Gales]], DE [[Bobby Greenwood (American football)|Bobby Greenwood]], G [[Darryl Harris]], RB [[Javarris Williams]] and WR [[Rodney Wright]] were added to the practice squad. After the first regular season game, the Chiefs waived LB [[Turk McBride]]. After the third game, the Chiefs traded QB [[Tyler Thigpen]] to the [[Miami Dolphins]] for an undisclosed draft pick.{{cite web | title=Dolphins get some insurance at QB | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4516236 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-09-29 | accessdate=2009-09-29}} ====Additions==== Despite having several needs to be addressed and nearly $35 million in salary cap room, the Chiefs were criticized for being "quiet" in free-agency after the Cassel/Vrabel trade, primarily adding back-up players for depth.{{cite web | title=AFC West Blog â Around AFC West â March 13, 2009 | url=http://myespn.go.com/blogs/afcwest/0-3-1769/Around-AFC-West.html | last=Williamson | first=Bill | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-03-13 | accessdate=2009-03-14}}{{cite web | title=AFC West Blog â Who is making the grade in the AFC West? â March 13, 2009 | url=http://myespn.go.com/blogs/afcwest/0-3-1768/Who-is-making-the-grade-in-the-AFC-West-.html | last=Williamson | first=Bill | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-03-13 | accessdate=2009-03-14}} In March, the Chiefs signed LB [[Darrell Robertson]],{{cite web | title=Kansas City agrees to terms with S Jon McGraw, LB Darrell Robertson | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/06/kansas_city_agrees_to_terms_with_s_jon_mcgraw_lb_darrell_robertson/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-06 | accessdate=2009-03-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} WR [[C. date=2009-11-03 | accessdate=2009-11-03}} =====Cassel/Vrabel trade===== [[File:Matt Cassell.jpg|right|thumb|Matt Cassel was acquired in February.]] On the first day of free agency (February 27), the Chiefs acquired LB [[Mike Vrabel]] from the Patriots for an undisclosed draft pick.{{cite web | title=Kansas City Chiefs acquire LB Mike Vrabel from Patriots | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3940213 | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-02-27 | accessdate=2009-02-27}}{{cite web | title=Chiefs acquire QB Matt Cassel, LB Mike Vrabel in trade with Patriots | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/02/28/chiefs_acquire_qb_matt_cassel_lb_mike_vrabel_in_trade_with_patriots/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-02-28 | accessdate=2009-02-28}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The ''[[Boston Globe]]'' speculated that it would be part of a bigger trade involving QB [[Matt Cassel]].{{cite web | title=Mike Vrabel analysis | url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/reiss_pieces/2009/02/mike_vrabel_ana.html | last=Reiss | first=Mike | publisher=Boston Globe | date=2009-02-28 | accessdate=2009-02-28}} The next day, the Chiefs confirmed the acquisition of both Vrabel and Cassel from New England in exchange for their second round draft selection in the [[2009 NFL Draft]] (#34 overall).{{cite web | title=Chiefs complete trade for Cassel | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/peter_king/02/28/chiefs.trade.for.cassel/index.html | last=King | first=Peter | publisher=Sports Illustrated | date=2009-02-28 | accessdate=2009-02-28}} Reactions to the trade were mixed and it was called "monumentally lopsided" with the Chiefs "clearly (getting) the better end of the deal."{{cite web | title=Chiefs keep quiet after landing Cassel, Vrabel in steal of a deal with Pats | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80f07e50&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true | author=Associated Press | publisher=NFL.com | date=2009-03-02 | accessdate=2009-03-07}} [[Don Banks]] of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' called the Chiefs the "big winners" of the first weekend of NFL free agency and the Patriots' compensation "laughably low," but the best they could get in return.{{cite web | title=Patriots could have asked for more | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/don_banks/02/28/cassel.traded.chiefs/index.html?eref=T1 | last=Banks | first=Don | publisher=Sports Illustrated | date=2009-02-28 | accessdate=2009-03-01}}{{cite web | title=Were the Patriots robbed by the Chiefs? Reaction is split | url=http://blogs.usatoday.com/thehuddle/2009/02/were-the-patrio.html | author=The Huddle | publisher=USA Today | date=2009-03-01 | accessdate=2009-03-01}} The trade was done mainly because the Patriots could not keep two quarterbacks on their roster that took up $29.2 million of salary cap space, so it was not a matter of if the Patriots would trade Cassel, but when. The Patriots also have [[Tom Brady]] under contract, who is recovering from a knee-injury sufffered in a 2008 game against the Chiefs.{{cite web | title=Matt Cassel analysis | url=http://www.boston.com/sports/football/patriots/reiss_pieces/ | last=Reiss | first=Mike | publisher=Boston Globe | date=2009-02-28 | accessdate=2009-02-28}} On July 15 the Chiefs signed Cassel to six-year contract extension worth a total of $63 million.{{cite web | title=Chiefs sign Cassel to long-term deal | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/nfl/07/14/cassel.ap/index.html | author=Associated Press | publisher=Sports Illustrated | date=2009-07-15 | accessdate=2009-07-15}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web | title=Chiefs QB Matt Cassel signs contract extension | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/07/14/chiefs_qb_matt_cassel_signs_contract_extension/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-07-14 | accessdate=2009-07-16}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ====Free agency==== {| class="wikitable" !Position || Player || Tag || Date signed || 2009 team || Contract

The Chiefs were later awarded the 256th and final selection in the [[2009 NFL Draft]], making them effectively choose "[[Mr. Irrelevant]]."{{cite web | title=Bengals, Titans awarded maximum four compensatory draft picks | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80f699b6&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true | publisher=NFL.com | date=2009-03-23 | accessdate=2009-03-24}} The player chosen was K [[Ryan Succop]], who was the Chiefs' first "Mr. Irrelevant" since the [[1970 NFL Draft]] when DB Rayford Jenkins was chosen by the team from [[Alcorn State University|Alcorn A&M]]. The Chiefs selected defensive end [[Tyson Jackson]] third overall. Jackson was the third consecutive first round pick by the Chiefs to have played collegiately for the [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]]. All terms of the contracts for the 2009 draft picks were undisclosed, but ESPN reported that Jackson signed a five-year contract worth $57 million, with $31 million guaranteed.{{cite web | Conditioning â [[Cedric Smith (American football)|Cedric Smith]] *Assistant Strength and Conditioning â [[Brent Salazar]] |} ==Preseason== The Chiefs conducted [[Training camp (National Football League)|training camp]] at the [[University of WisconsinâRiver Falls]] for the 19th and final consecutive year.{{cite web | title=Au Revoir, River Falls | url=http://www.kcchiefs.com/news/2009/08/21/au_revoir_river_falls/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | last=Moris | first=Pete | date=2009-08-21 | accessdate=2009-09-06}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The team will move training camp to [[St. Joseph, Missouri]] in 2010. They lost all four games in the [[National Football League exhibition season|preseason]] to the [[Houston Texans]], [[Minnesota Vikings]], [[Seattle Seahawks]], and [[St. Louis Rams]] (for the [[Governor's Cup (Missouri)|Missouri Governor's Cup]]).{{cite web | title=Chiefs preseason opponents set for 2009 | url=http://kcchiefs.com/news/2009/03/30/chiefs_preseason_opponents_set_for_2009/ | publisher=Kansas City Chiefs | date=2009-03-30 | accessdate=2009-03-30}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In the Chiefs' game against the Seahawks, QB Matt Cassel suffered a sprained [[Medial collateral ligament]] (MCL), leaving his status as starting quarterback for opening day in doubt.{{cite web | title=Yahoo: Matt Cassel has MCL sprain, could miss Week 1 | url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/thehuddle/post/2009/08/yahoo-matt-cassel-has-mcl-strain-could-miss-week-1/1 | publisher=USA Today | last=Leahy | first=Sean | date=2009-08-30 | accessdate=2009-09-06}} The offense for the Chiefs struggled in all four games, scoring only 42 points in four games and the offensive line suffered numerous breakdowns which led to Cassel's injury.{{cite web | title=Cassel leaves game with injured leg | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/30/sports/football/30nfl.html?_r=1 | publisher=New York Times | author=Associated Press | date=2009-08-29 | accessdate=2009-09-06}} The offensive struggles led to offensive coordinator [[Chan Gailey]]'s firing and head coach [[Todd Haley]] assuming playcalling duties. ==Regular season results== ===Week 1: at Baltimore Ravens=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Chiefs |R1=0||R2=7||R3=7||R4=10||RT=24 |Home='''Ravens''' |H1=10||H2=0||H3=7||H4=21||HT=38 |stadium= [[M&T Bank Stadium]], [[Baltimore, Maryland]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 76Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 71,099 |referee=[[Gene Steratore]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} The Chiefs began their season at [[M&T Bank Stadium]] against the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Due to his injured knee, quarterback [[Matt Cassel]] was unable to play, so [[Brodie Croyle]] got the start.{{cite web | title=Haley: Cassel (knee) a question mark | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4476194 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-09-16 | accessdate=2009-09-17}} Despite completing 16-of-24 passes for 177 yards and two touchdowns, the Chiefs lost to the Ravens 38â24, and Croyle fell to 0â9 as a starter.{{cite web | title=Kansas City 24, Baltimore 38 | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=290913033 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-09-13 | accessdate=2009-09-17}}{{cite web | title=Cassel picks up pace in practice | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4478102 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-09-16 | accessdate=2009-09-17}} Kansas City trailed in the first quarter as Ravens kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] got a 44-yard field goal, followed by quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] completing a 3-yard touchdown pass to running back [[Willis McGahee]]. In the second quarter, the Chiefs got on the board as safety [[Jon McGraw]] recovered a blocked punt in the end zone for a touchdown. In the third quarter, Kansas City took the lead as Croyle completed a 2-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Dwayne Bowe]], yet Baltimore answered with Flacco completing a 9-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Todd Heap]]. What followed was a back-and-forth battle in the fourth quarter. Chiefs kicker [[Ryan Succop]] got a 53-yard field goal, but the Ravens replied with fullback [[Le'Ron McClain]] getting a 1-yard touchdown run. Kansas City would stay close as Croyle completed a 10-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Sean Ryan (American football)|Sean Ryan]], but Baltimore would pull away as Flacco completed a 31-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Mark J. Clayton|Mark Clayton]] and McGahee getting a 1-yard touchdown run. With the loss, the Chiefs began their season at 0â1. ===Week 2: vs. Oakland Raiders=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Raiders''' |R1=0||R2=3||R3=3||R4=7||RT=13 |Home=Chiefs |H1=3||H2=0||H3=0||H4=7||HT=10 |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 72Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 69,169 |referee= [[Walt Anderson (American football)|Walt Anderson]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] }} Hoping to rebound from their tough road loss to the Ravens, the Chiefs played their Week 2 home opener against their AFC West foe, the [[Oakland Raiders]]. Kansas City would score in the first quarter as rookie kicker [[Ryan Succop]] got a 23-yard field goal. In the second quarter, the Raiders tied the game as kicker [[Sebastian Janikowski]] made a 48-yard field goal. Oakland would take the lead in the third quarter as Janikowski nailed a 54-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, the Chiefs would retake the lead as quarterback [[Matt Cassel]] completed a 29-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Dwayne Bowe]]. However, the Raiders sealed the win as running back [[Darren McFadden]] got a 5-yard touchdown run. With the loss, Kansas City fell to 0â2. ===Week 3: at Philadelphia Eagles=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Chiefs |R1=0||R2=7||R3=0||R4=7||RT=14 |Home='''Eagles''' |H1=14||H2=10||H3=3||H4=7||HT=34 |stadium= [[Lincoln Financial Field]], [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 69Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 69,144 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] }} Still searching for their first win of the season, the Chiefs flew to [[Lincoln Financial Field]] for a Week 3 interconference duel with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. Kansas City would trail early in the first quarter as Eagles running back [[LeSean McCoy]] got a 5-yard touchdown run and quarterback [[Kevin Kolb]] got a 1-yard touchdown run. The Chiefs would get on the board with quarterback [[Matt Cassel]]'s 13-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Mark Bradley]], but Philadelphia came right back with Kolb's 64-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[DeSean Jackson]] and kicker [[David Akers]]' 29-yard field goal. Kansas City's deficit would increase as Akers nailed a 38-yard field goal in the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, the Eagles would put the game away with Kolb's 35-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Brent Celek]]. Afterwards, the Chiefs would end the game with Cassel's 9-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Bobby Wade]]. With the loss, Kansas City fell to 0â3. ===Week 4: vs. New York Giants=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Giants''' |R1=7||R2=10||R3=3||R4=7||RT=27 |Home=Chiefs |H1=3||H2=0||H3=0||H4=13||HT=16 |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00pm EDT |weather= 59Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 69,238 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]], [[Daryl Johnston]], & [[Tony Siragusa]] }} After a brutal road loss to the Eagles, the Chiefs went home for a Week 4 interconference duel with the [[New York Giants]]. Kansas City would trail in the first quarter with quarterback [[Eli Manning]] completing a 3-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Steve Smith (New York Giants)|Steve Smith]]. Afterwards, the Chiefs would get on the board with rookie kicker [[Ryan Succop]]'s 34-yard field goal. In the second quarter, New York would answer with Manning hooking up with Smith again on a 25-yard touchdown pass. Then, the Giants would close out the half with former Chiefs kicker [[Lawrence Tynes]] making a 25-yard field goal. After Tynes' 40-yard field goal in the third quarter, New York would finish their scoring in the fourth quarter with quarterback [[Eli Manning]]'s 54-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Hakeem Nicks]]. Kansas City tried to rally with quarterback [[Matt Cassel]] completing a 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Sean Ryan (American football)|Sean Ryan]] (followed by a failed 2-point conversion) and a 2-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Bobby Wade]]. With the loss, the Chiefs fell to 0â4. ===Week 5: vs. Dallas Cowboys=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Cowboys''' |R1=0||R2=3||R3=7||R4=10||R5=6||RT=26 |Home=Chiefs |H1=0||H2=10||H3=3||H4=7||H5=0||HT=20 |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00pm EDT |weather= 40Â°F (Overcast) |attendance= 71,214 |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Joe Buck]], [[Troy Aikman]], & [[Pam Oliver]] }} Still looking to acquire their first win of the year, the Chiefs stayed at home, donned their Dallas Texans throwbacks, and played a Week 5 interconference duel with the [[Dallas Cowboys]]. After a scoreless first quarter, Kansas City got out of the gates in the second quarter as kicker [[Ryan Succop]] made a 47-yard field goal and quarterback [[Matt Cassel]] completed a 1-yard touchdown pass to linebacker [[Mike Vrabel]]. Afterwards, the Cowboys closed out the opening half with a 22-yard field goal from kicker [[Nick Folk]]. The Chiefs went back to work in the third quarter with Succop booting a 38-yard field goal, yet Dallas began to rally with a 36-yard touchdown run from running back [[Tashard Choice]]. Dallas would take the lead in the fourth quarter as Folk nailed a 28-yard field goal and quarterback [[Tony Romo]] found wide receiver [[Miles Austin]] on a 59-yard touchdown pass, yet Kansas City would tie the game as Cassel hooked up with wide receiver [[Dwayne Bowe]] on a 16-yard touchdown pass. However, the Cowboys won it in overtime as Romo threw the game-ending 60-yard touchdown pass to Austin. With the tough loss, the Chiefs fell to 0â5. ===Week 6: at Washington Redskins=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Chiefs''' |R1=0||R2=3||R3=3||R4=8||RT=14 |Home=Redskins |H1=0||H2=0||H3=6||H4=0||HT=6 |stadium= [[FedEx Field|Fed Ex Field]], [[Landover, Maryland]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 45Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 79,572 |referee= [[Tony Corrente]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} Following a tough overtime loss to the Cowboys, the Chiefs flew to [[FedEx Field|Fed Ex Field]] for a Week 6 interconference duel with the [[Washington Redskins]]. After a scoreless first quarter, Chiefs kicker [[Ryan Succop]] booted a 39-yard field goal for the only score of the half. In the third quarter, the Redskins took the lead with a 40-yard and a 28-yard field goal from kicker [[Shaun Suisham]], but Kansas City tied it up with Succop's 46-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, Succop gave the Chiefs the lead with a 46-yard and a 24-yard field, but it was the defense that closed the game out for Kansas City, as DE/OLB [[Tamba Hali]] sacked quarterback [[Todd Collins (quarterback)|Todd Collins]] in his own end zone for a safety with under a minute to play. With the win, the Chiefs improved to 1â5. ===Week 7: vs. San Diego Chargers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Chargers''' |R1=14||R2=6||R3=7||R4=10||RT=37 |Home=Chiefs |H1=0||H2=0||H3=7||H4=0||HT=7 |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 58Â°F (Overcast) |attendance= 69,337 |referee= [[Pete Morelli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} Coming off their road win over the Redskins, the Chiefs went home, donned their Dallas Texans throwbacks, and played a Week 7 AFL Legacy game with the [[San Diego Chargers]]. Kansas City would find themselves trailing in the first quarter as Chargers quarterback [[Philip Rivers]] completed a 3-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Malcom Floyd]], followed by a 10-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Vincent Jackson]]. San Diego would add onto their lead in the second quarter with a 20-yard and a 39-yard field goal from kicker [[Nate Kaeding]]. The Chiefs would get onto the board in the third quarter with quarterback [[Matt Cassel]] completing a 7-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Dwayne Bowe]], but the Chargers kept their momentum going with Rivers finding running back [[Darren Sproles]] on a 58-yard touchdown pass. In the fourth quarter, San Diego sealed the win with Kaeding's 19-yard field goal and fullback [[Jacob Hester]] recovering a blocked punt in the end zone for a touchdown. With the loss, Kansas City went into their bye week at 1â6. ====Suspension of Larry Johnson==== [[Larry Johnson (American football)|Larry Johnson]] was suspended for two weeks after he made offensive comments about [[Todd Haley]] and made offensive comments about [[homosexuals]] on [[Twitter]] and in public.{{cite web | title=Johnson suspended until November 9 | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4603752 | publisher=ESPN.com | author=Associated Press | date=2009-10-28 | accessdate=2009-10-28}} ===Week 8: BYE=== {{Empty section|date=January 2011}} ===Week 9: at Jacksonville Jaguars=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Chiefs |R1=3||R2=3||R3=0||R4=15||RT=21| |Home='''Jaguars''' |H1=7||H2=7||H3=3||H4=7||HT=24| |stadium= [[Jacksonville Municipal Stadium]], [[Jacksonville, Florida]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 75Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 45,546 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Bill Macatee]] & [[Steve Beuerlein]] }} After their bye week, the Chiefs flew to Jacksonville Municipal Stadium for an Intraconference Duel with the Jaguars. While the Chiefs got on the board first with [[Ryan Succop]] nailing a 45-yard goal, they fell behind when [[Rashad Jennings]] ran from the 28-yard line to the end zone for a touchdown. In the second quarter [[Ryan Succop]] made a 21-yard field goal, and then the Jaguars scored when [[David Garrard]] completed a 61-yard touchdown pass to [[Mike Sims-Walker]]. The only score in the third quarter was when [[Josh Scobee]] hit a 27-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter the Chiefs fell further behind when [[Maurice Jones-Drew]] got a 10-yard touchdown run. The Chiefs tried to come back with [[Matt Cassel]] completing a 54-yard and a 5-yard touchdown pass to [[Chris Chambers]] (Second time round the two-point conversion was made when [[Matt Cassel]] passed to [[Jamaal Charles]]) but couldn't go any further thanks to the Jaguars' defense resulting in a loss. With the loss, the Chiefs fell to 1â7. ===Week 10: at Oakland Raiders=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Chiefs''' |R1=3||R2=10||R3=0||R4=3||RT=16| |Home=Raiders |H1=10||H2=0||H3=0||H4=0||HT=10| |stadium= [[Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum]], [[Oakland, California]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 60Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 40,720 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] & [[Steve Tasker]] }} Trying to snap a two-game losing streak, the Chiefs flew to the [[Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum]], donned their Dallas Texans throwbacks, and played a Week 10 AFC Legacy game with perennial rival, the [[Oakland Raiders]]. Kansas City would trail in the first quarter as Raiders running back [[Justin Fargas]] got a 1-yard touchdown run. The Chiefs would get on the board with rookie kicker [[Ryan Succop]] getting a 50-yard field goal, but Oakland would strike back as kicker [[Sebastian Janikowski]] got a 50-yard field goal. Kansas City would take the lead in the second quarter with a 44-yard touchdown run from running back [[Jamaal Charles]], followed by Succop nailing a 25-yard field goal. After a scoreless third quarter, Succop would come through for the Chiefs in the fourth quarter with a 31-yard field goal. With the win, Kansas City improved to 2â7. ===Week 11: vs. Pittsburgh Steelers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Steelers |R1=0||R2=17||R3=0||R4=7||R5=0||RT= |Home='''Chiefs''' |H1=7||H2=0||H3=10||H4=7||H5=3||HT= |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 55Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 70,261 |referee= [[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] }} The Chiefs returned home to host the [[Pittsburgh Steelers|Steelers]] in an attempt to create the biggest upset of the weekThe Steelers were favored by 11.5 points on Yahoo's combined line odds (which is removed from online view when the game begins), the widest margin for Week 11 in the NFL. and get their first back-to-back wins since 2007. Optimism grew quickly as [[Jamaal Charles]] ran the opening kick 97 yards for a touchdown, starting the game with a 7â0 Chiefs lead. The Steelers dominated the rest of the first half with 20:45 time of possession, going into halftime with a 17â7 lead. The Chiefs' defense began to pressure [[Ben Rothlisberger]] in the third quarter, forcing two interceptions (both by [[Andy Studebaker]] in his first NFL start). By the fourth quarter, the Chiefs tied the game up at 17â17. The fourth quarter resulted in a touchdown each, sending the game into overtime. The Steelers won the toss in overtime, but failed to get within field goal range. Of note, Rothlisberger suffered a knee to the head concussion and was replaced by [[Charlie Batch]]. The Chiefs took over at the 20 and, after a 61 yard catch and run by [[Chris Chambers]], [[Ryan Succop]] kicked the winning 22 yard field goal. With the win, the Chiefs improved to 3â7 and snapped a 10-game home losing streak, the longest in team history. ===Week 12: at San Diego Chargers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Chiefs |R1=0||R2=7||R3=7||R4=0||RT=14 |Home='''Chargers''' |H1=7||H2=21||H3=10||H4=5||HT=43 |stadium= [[Qualcomm Stadium]], [[San Diego, California]] |time= 4:05 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 63Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 65,280 |referee= [[Don Carey (official)|Don Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} Coming off their win against the Steelers, the Chiefs went on the road for an AFC West rivalry match against the [[San Diego Chargers]]. In the first quarter the Chiefs trailed early as QB [[Philip Rivers]] got a 19-yard touchdown pass to TE [[Antonio Gates]]. The Chiefs would reply to tie the game with QB [[Matt Cassel]] making a 7-yard touchdown pass to WR [[Chris Chambers]], until they fell back again with RB [[LaDainian Tomlinson]] getting a 1-yard touchdown run, then Rivers hooking up with Gates again on a 15-yard touchdown pass, then DB [[Paul Oliver (American football)|Paul Oliver]] returned a fumble 40 yards for a touchdown. In the third quarter the Chiefs' struggle continued as RB [[LaDainian Tomlinson]] got a 3-yard touchdown run. They tried to come back with RB [[Jamaal Charles]] getting a 2-yard touchdown run, but the Chargers would pull away with kicker [[Nate Kaeding]] making a 55-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter the problem got worse when a penalty on [[Matt Cassel]] was enforced in the end zone for a safety, giving the Chargers 2 points. The final score was made when Kaeding booted a 23-yard field goal. With the loss, the Chiefs fell to 3â8. ===Week 13: vs. Denver Broncos=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Broncos''' |R1=7||R2=7||R3=20||R4=10||RT= |Home=Chiefs |H1=0||H2=6||H3=0||H4=7||HT= |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 37Â°F (Overcast) |attendance= 68,912 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Enberg]] & [[Dan Fouts]] }} The Chiefs defense began the game by demonstrating how unpredictable they have been all season. After giving up three plays of 10 yards or more, [[Mike Brown (American football)|Mike Brown]] intercepted what would likely have been a touchdown pass, giving the Chiefs offense a chance to take the field. After a short run and two incomplete passes, the Chiefs punted back to Denver. The Chiefs defense nearly forced the Broncos to a three-and-out, but the drive was kept going by a [[Ron Edwards (American football)|Ron Edwards]] face mask call. The end result was a [[Kyle Orton]] to [[Daniel Graham]] touchdown pass. The Chiefs offense responded by putting together a relatively long series that began at the KC 31 and lasted 20 plays, ending in a 22 yard [[Ryan Succop]] field goal. After a couple possession changes, the Broncos answered with a series that included three [[Correll Buckhalter]] rushes for over 10 yards, ending in a [[Knowshon Moreno]] rushing touchdown. The Chiefs would respond before the half with another field goal. The second began with the Chiefs failing to convert on fourth down and the Broncos scoring on each of their first three possessions. Before the end of the quarter, [[Matt Cassel]] was replaced by [[Brodie Croyle]]. After the Chiefs lost a [[Jamal Charles]] fumble for a touchdown, they recovered a Kyle Orton fumble and eventually turned it into a Jamal Charles rushing touchdown. The Broncos immediately responded with yet another touchdown. With the loss, the Chiefs fall to 3â9. ===Week 14: vs. Buffalo Bills=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bills''' |R1=7||R2=3||R3=3||R4=3||RT= |Home=Chiefs |H1=0||H2=3||H3=7||H4=0||HT= |stadium=
